title: What is meant by studying scientifically? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Studying scientifically means using 1) a scientific method and studying 2) natural phenomena. To expand this a bit, the scientific method consists of: I Observation – Empirical (given to the senses) experience and establishes facts as mutually agreed upon experiences (phenomena); inductive in that past experiences qualify new experiences and are determined by frames of reference; limited in that senses cannot perceive full spectrum of electromagnetic/mechanical signals. II Hypothesis – A causal explanation for an observation; must be empirically deterministic; may be imaginative and metaphoric, yet deductive in formulation; probabilistic until verified by additional evidence or test results; may be built from prior hypotheses of varying degrees of verification; the best hypotheses rise to the level of law (paradigm) because of continued verification or applicability across broad spectrum of phenomena, but never achieve 100% certainty; same as a theory. III Experiment, Test or Measurement – Demonstrates in an attempted closed system (controlled variables) whether the hypothesis supports the causal explanation for the observation; with some phenomena not being capable of demonstration and only being measurable. IV Conclusion – Deductive assessment whether the experiment demonstrated the causal explanation for the phenomena in a closed system; results in a probability statement; hypotheses can be proved absolutely false, but do not achieve absolute truth because all through all time cannot be achieved (induction). V Prediction – Inductively predicts future encounters with the phenomena will be causally explained by the hypothesis; verification of the hypothesis by the collection of subsequent same or similar evidence though experiment, test or measurement; verification by enumeration contributes to the probability that the hypothesis is true, but absolute proof (truth) is never achieved; often presents the challenge: it ought to be there if you look. VI Consensus – Agreement among scientists following verification by enumerated conclusions that the prevailing hypothesis is supported by the evidence; establishes the paradigm or ruling theory within scientific categories of study; the most social and political of all steps of the scientific method even though the ends of science are not popularly or democratically determined. Note: This is not “THE” scientific method as there are many variations based on the kind of phenomena being studied and the research methodology employed. For example, quantum physics is vastly different than geology. “Naturalism” distinguishes the subjects of the sciences from “supernaturalism,” with the point being that nature causes nature. Being able to universally share experience as fact with anyone at anytime (with the proper extension of our senses via technology) establishes a “fact” or mutually agreed upon experience. Even so, our collective experience may be wrong. For example, we say the sun rises and sets, which is not at all what happens. When we look more closely with telescopes and measure what we see against a hypothesis, we see behind the illusions of our shared experiences.

It means you apply the scientific method to the inquiry. Come up with a hypothesis — a possible explanation of the phenomenon under study. Then design an experiment. The experiment should remove all variables from the process except the cause under investigation. Now see if measured changes in that cause produce the effect desired. If it does, share the method and results so that other scientists can repeat the experiment and confirm your findings or not.

It means you try to disprove the hypothesis you’ve concocted to explain the thing you are studying. It means that if you succeed in disproving your hypothesis, you abandon it. It means that if your hypothesis survives your attacks, that it’s only an indication that your hypothesis holds for now. It means you want other scientists to try to disprove it even more than you did. It means if other scientists disprove your hypothesis, you abandon it. It means that if your hypothesis survives their attacks, then your hypothesis holds for now. That it’s about as good as it gets.

{subjective and not by any means a complete definition} Thorough, logical, implying cause and effect relations. Preferably dealing with measurable values. A study where any hypothesis can be reliably proved right or wrong.

Scientists work in a disciplined way (the scientific method). Everything is quantified, logged, with the idea that experiments may be repeated and validated by others. Hypotheses are drawn up for further experimentation and conclusions are drawn. Everything is done objectively.
